items.title: Welcome to Homelab
items.text: A production-grade infrastructure automation project demonstrating modern DevOps practices and cloud-native technologies.

items.text:

items.title: The Stack
items.text:
Infrastructure as Code

Proxmox VE hosts everything. Packer builds golden images. OpenTofu provisions VMs. K3s runs containers. Argo CD deploys apps.

items.title: Quick Start
items.text:
Deploy the entire stack with a single command:

atmos workflow deploy-homelab -f stacks/workflows/deploy.yaml

items.title: Setting Up Development Environment
items.text:
1. Fork the repository
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/homelab.git
cd homelab
  1. Create a branch
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

  1. Make your changes

  2. Follow existing code style

  3. Update documentation

  4. Add tests if applicable

  5. Test your changes

# Validate Atmos configuration
atmos validate stacks

# Validate Packer templates
atmos packer validate alma9-k3s-optimized -s pve-prod

# Validate OpenTofu configuration
atmos terraform validate k3s-cluster -s pve-prod
  1. Commit and push
git add .
git commit -m "feat: add your feature description"
git push origin feature/your-feature-name
  1. Open a Pull Request

items.title: Getting Started
items.text: Welcome! This guide will help you deploy the homelab infrastructure from scratch.

items.title: What You'll Learn
items.text:
• Prerequisites and required tools
  • Installation steps
  • Configuration basics
  • Your first deployment

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text: Before you begin, ensure you have:

items.title: Hardware Requirements
items.text:
• Proxmox VE Server: Physical server or nested virtualization
  • Minimum: 8GB RAM, 4 CPU cores, 100GB storage
  • Recommended: 32GB+ RAM, 8+ CPU cores, 500GB+ storage
  • Development Machine: Linux, macOS, or Windows with WSL2
  • Network: Connectivity between your machine and Proxmox

items.title: Software Requirements
items.text:
• Basic knowledge of Linux, VMs, and Kubernetes
  • Git for version control
  • SSH access to Proxmox host

items.title: Installation
items.text: Install the required tools on your development machine:

items.title: 1. Install Atmos
items.text:
macOS (Homebrew)

brew install atmos

Linux

curl -fsSL https://atmos.tools/install.sh | bash

Verify

atmos version

items.title: 2. Install Packer
items.text:
macOS (Homebrew)

brew install packer

Linux

# Download from https://www.packer.io/downloads

Verify

packer version

items.title: 3. Install OpenTofu
items.text:
macOS (Homebrew)

brew install opentofu

Linux

# Download from https://opentofu.org/docs/intro/install/

Verify

tofu version

items.title: 4. Install kubectl
items.text:
macOS (Homebrew)

brew install kubectl

Linux

curl -LO "https://dl.k8s.io/release/$(curl -L -s https://dl.k8s.io/release/stable.txt)/bin/linux/amd64/kubectl"
chmod +x kubectl
sudo mv kubectl /usr/local/bin/

Verify

kubectl version --client

items.title: 1. Clone the Repository
items.text:
git clone https://github.com/cwagne17/homelab.git
cd homelab

items.title: 2. Configure Proxmox Access
items.text:
Set up API credentials:

export PROXMOX_TOKEN="your-api-token"
export PM_API_TOKEN_SECRET="your-api-token"

items.title: 3. Validate Configuration
items.text: atmos validate stacks

items.title: Quick Deploy
items.text:
Deploy the entire stack:

atmos workflow deploy-homelab -f stacks/workflows/deploy.yaml

This will:

  1. Build a k3s-optimized AlmaLinux 9 image
  2. Provision a VM on Proxmox
  3. Bootstrap Kubernetes with Argo CD
  4. Deploy applications via GitOps

items.title: Common Issues
items.text:
Packer build fails

  • Check Proxmox API credentials
  • Verify network connectivity
  • Ensure sufficient storage space

OpenTofu apply fails

  • Verify template exists in Proxmox
  • Check VM resource availability
  • Review OpenTofu state

Kubernetes bootstrap fails

  • Verify VM is running
  • Check k3s service status
  • Review kubectl connectivity

items.title: Architecture Overview
items.text:
The homelab uses a pipeline approach:

  1. Packer builds golden VM images with k3s pre-installed
  2. OpenTofu provisions VMs on Proxmox from those images
  3. K3s provides the Kubernetes platform
  4. Argo CD deploys applications via GitOps

items.title: Quick Deploy
items.text:
For the impatient, here's the one-command deployment:

atmos workflow deploy-homelab -f stacks/workflows/deploy.yaml

Prerequisites Required

Make sure you've completed the Setup steps first!

items.title: K3s Kubernetes
items.text: K3s is a lightweight Kubernetes distribution designed for edge computing and resource-constrained environments.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
K3s powers the container orchestration in the homelab:

  • Lightweight: Minimal resource footprint
  • Production-Ready: Full Kubernetes API compatibility
  • GitOps: Argo CD for application deployment
  • Easy Management: Single binary installation

items.title: OpenTofu Infrastructure
items.text: OpenTofu is an open-source infrastructure-as-code tool for provisioning and managing cloud infrastructure.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
OpenTofu manages all infrastructure in the homelab:

  • Declarative Configuration: Infrastructure defined as code
  • Proxmox Provider: Automated VM provisioning
  • State Management: Track infrastructure changes
  • Modular Design: Reusable components

items.title: Infrastructure Components
items.text:
• k3s Cluster: Single-node Kubernetes cluster
  • VM Configuration: CPU, memory, disk, networking
  • Cloud-init: Automated VM initialization
  • Networking: Static IP configuration

items.title: Packer Image Building
items.text: HashiCorp Packer automates the creation of machine images for multiple platforms from a single source configuration.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
Packer builds golden images for the homelab:

  • AlmaLinux 9 Base: RHEL-compatible Linux distribution
  • k3s Pre-installed: Kubernetes ready on first boot
  • Automated Builds: Reproducible image creation
  • Version Control: Semantic versioning for images

items.text:

  • UEFI boot support

items.title: Proxmox VE
items.text: Proxmox Virtual Environment is an open-source virtualization platform that combines KVM hypervisor and LXC containers.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
In this homelab, Proxmox VE serves as the foundation for all infrastructure:

  • Virtualization Platform: Hosts all VMs including the k3s cluster
  • API Integration: Automated VM provisioning via OpenTofu
  • Template Storage: Stores golden images built by Packer
  • Resource Management: Manages compute, storage, and networking

items.title: Key Features
items.text:
• Web-based management interface
  • RESTful API for automation
  • High availability clustering support
  • Integrated backup and restore
  • Software-defined networking
